choices.text: Increase in range of the confidence interval
Decrease in standard deviation
Decrease in standard error of the mean
Increase in probability of type II error

questions.text: A researcher is examining the relationship between socioeconomic status and IQ scores. Initially, the researcher obtains a random sampling of 300 high school students from public schools nationwide and conducts IQ tests on all participants. Recently, the researcher received additional funding to enable an increase in sample size to 2,000 participants. Assuming that all other study conditions are held constant, which of the following is most likely to occur as a result of this additional funding?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Decrease in standard error of the mean

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of painless lesions on his face that he has had since shortly after birth. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Capillary hemangioma

questions.text:
What are the indicators that suggest CPR is of high quality?

 

  1. Chest compression at a rate of 100-120/minute
  2. Breathing rate of 20-25/minute
  3. Depth of compression should be 5-6 cm
  4. Allow chest recoil
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1, 3, 4 only

choices.text: Irritable bowel syndrome

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue, intermittent abdominal pain, and bulky, foul-smelling diarrhea. She has had a 4-kg weight loss during this period despite no changes in appetite. Examination of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Staining of the stool with Sudan III stain shows a large number of red droplets. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Celiac disease

questions.text: A research group wants to assess the safety and toxicity profile of a new drug. A clinical trial is conducted with 20 volunteers to estimate the maximum tolerated dose and monitor the apparent toxicity of the drug. The study design is best described as which of the following phases of a clinical trial?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Phase I

questions.text: A 60-year-old man on mechanical ventilation shows an increased peak pressure during inspiration. What does peak pressure indicate?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Airway resistance

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue and yellowish discoloration of her skin. During this period, she has also had a 6 kg weight gain. She does not smoke and drinks one glass of wine daily. She follows a vegan diet that consists mainly of spinach, kale, and sweet potatoes. Physical examination shows yellowing of the skin. Her hands are cold to the touch and her nails appear brittle. Eye examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following findings is most likely in this patient's serum?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased beta-carotene concentration

 

This presentation is most consistent with carotenemia — excess dietary beta-carotene (from foods like spinach, kale, sweet potato) causing yellow-orange discoloration of the skin while sparing the sclera. The patient’s weight gain, cold hands, and brittle nails point to possible hypothyroidism, which can reduce conversion of carotene to vitamin A, worsening carotene accumulation. Carotenemia is benign and shows elevated serum beta-carotene without the laboratory pattern of hepatobiliary disease or hemolysis. Management is dietary modification and treating any underlying hypothyroidism if present. An image below shows Yellow orange discoloration of Carotenemia hand compared to subject reference on left side.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased haptoglobin concentration: Low haptoglobin indicates intravascular hemolysis (hemoglobin released binds haptoglobin), seen with anemia, jaundice, dark urine, and often reticulocytosis. This patient lacks systemic hemolytic signs (no scleral icterus, no pallor described), so low haptoglobin is unlikely.

 

Option B. Increased alkaline phosphatase concentration: An elevated ALP suggests cholestasis or biliary obstruction (or bone disease). Those conditions commonly produce scleral icterus, pale stools, pruritus, and markedly abnormal liver panel .

 

Option C. Positive antimitochondrial antibodies: AMA positivity is characteristic of primary biliary cholangitis, which causes progressive cholestasis in middle-aged women with pruritus, fatigue, and elevated ALP.

choices.text: Aerobic during the day and anaerobic during the night
Anaerobic during the day and aerobic during the night

questions.text: A 40-year-old environmental engineer is explaining the functioning of oxidation ponds in wastewater treatment to a group of trainees. He describes how these ponds operate differently during the day and night. Which method do oxidation ponds use?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Aerobic during the day and anaerobic during the night

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of severe epigastric pain and nausea. She has a 20-year history of alcohol use disorder. Nine hours after admission, she becomes increasingly dyspneic and tachypneic. Pulse oximetry on supplemental oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 81%. Physical examination shows diffuse lung crackles, marked epigastric tenderness, and a periumbilical hematoma. Laboratory studies show normal brain natriuretic peptide. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral opacities in the lower lung fields. Which of the following pathomechanisms best explains this patient's pulmonary findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alveolocapillary membrane leakage

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), characterized by alveolocapillary membrane leakage leading to non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Intrapulmonary left-to-right shunt: Does not cause hypoxemia and bilateral lung opacities as seen here. 

 

Option C. Increased production of surfactant: Surfactant production is typically decreased in ARDS, worsening lung compliance. 

 

Option D. Embolic obstruction of pulmonary arteries: Pulmonary embolism usually presents with sudden chest pain and localized infarction, not diffuse bilateral opacities.

choices.text: Increased negative predictive value
Increased positive predictive value

questions.text: A group of investigators who are studying individuals infected with Trypanosoma cruzi is evaluating the ELISA absorbance cutoff value of serum samples for diagnosis of infection. The previous cutoff point is found to be too high, and the researchers decide to lower the threshold by 15%. Which of the following outcomes is most likely to result from this decision?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Increased negative predictive value

choices.text: Toxin-induced cleavage of desmoglein
Bacterial production of erythrogenic toxin
Bacterial invasion of the epidermis
Autoantibody deposition in stratum spinosum

questions.text: A previously healthy 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of fever, irritability, and rash for 3 days. The rash started around the mouth before spreading to the trunk and extremities. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F). Examination shows a diffuse erythematous rash with flaccid bullae on the neck, flexural creases, and buttocks. Gentle pressure across the trunk with a gloved finger creates a blister. Oropharyngeal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of these skin findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Toxin-induced cleavage of desmoglein

choices.text: Viral entry into host cell
Viral polypeptide cleavage
Viral DNA integration into host DNA
Reverse transcription of viral RNA

questions.text: An investigator is studying an experimental treatment for HIV infection that inhibits the maturation of new HIV virions. Patients who are taking the drug are observed for several years and side effects are recorded. A correlation is established between the drug and the development of impaired glucose tolerance. In addition, a significant portion of the patients who take the drug for several years develop kidney stones and show increased fat accumulation in the neck with loss of subcutaneous fat in the face and extremities. Which of the following processes is most likely targeted by this drug?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Viral polypeptide cleavage

choices.text: Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR
Check carotid pulse, Start CPR, call for help and activate ERS, Defibrillate
Defibrillate, assess response, check carotid pulse, Maintain airway
Start CPR, Activate ERS, Defibrillate, Check pulse

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence for CPR in Basic life support?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, is brought to the emergency department by her husband after an episode of unconsciousness. She delivered a healthy infant two weeks ago and the postpartum course was complicated by severe vaginal bleeding, for which she required 4 units of packed red blood cells. Since the blood transfusion, she has had decreased milk production and has felt fatigued. Her pulse is 118/min and blood pressure is 104/63 mm Hg. Her finger-stick glucose concentration is 34 mg/dL.Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Pituitary ischemia

questions.text: An investigator is conducting a study to identify potential risk factors for post-transplant hypertension. The investigator selects post-transplant patients with hypertension and gathers detailed information regarding their age, gender, preoperative blood pressure readings, and current medications. The results of the study reveal that some of the patients had been treated with cyclosporine. This study is best described as which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Case series

questions.text: A couple has four children, all unvaccinated for measles. One child contracted measles on August 5, 2015, and two other children developed measles by August 15, 2015. What is the secondary attack rate?
questions.solution: Ans. C) 66%

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of a rash on the thigh for 10 days. He reports that the rash has been enlarging and is intensely itchy. Two weeks ago, he adopted a stray dog from an animal shelter. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the examination findings is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Dermatophyte infection

questions.text: Under NTEP 2020, which of the following is ICT enabled adherence system?
questions.solution: Ans. C) DOTS-99

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman comes to the doctor because of gradually progressive weakness in her right hand over the past few weeks. She goes to the gym to lift weights 5 times a week. With the dorsum of the right hand on a flat surface, the patient is unable to move her thumb to touch a pen held 2 cm above the interphalangeal joint of the thumb. An MRI of the right arm shows compression of a nerve that passes through the pronater teres muscle. Based on the examination findings, loss of innervation of which of the following muscles is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abductor pollicis brevis

 

The abductor pollicis brevis is innervated by the median nerve (recurrent branch) which passes under the pronator teres muscle, fitting the scenario of compressive neuropathy seen in gym exercises. Loss of abductor pollicis brevis function impairs thumb abduction and opposition, explaining inability to lift the thumb towards an object above the dorsal surface. The clinical test and MRI findings confirm median nerve compression affecting thenar muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adductor pollicis: Innervated by the ulnar nerve (deep branch) and controls thumb adduction, not affected by median nerve or pronator teres compression.

 

Option C. Extensor pollicis brevis: Supplied by the posterior interosseous branch of the radial nerve, responsible for extension of the thumb at the MCP joint, not abduction.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis longus: Innervated by the radial nerve, acts on thumb abduction but is not impaired with median nerve compression in the pronator teres.

questions.text: During a clinical study on an island with a population of 2500 individuals, 500 are found to have fasting hyperglycemia. Analysis of medical records of deceased individuals shows that the average age of onset of fasting hyperglycemia is 45 years, and the average life expectancy is 70 years. Assuming a steady state of population on the island with no change in environmental risk factors, which of the following is the best estimate of the number of individuals who would newly develop fasting hyperglycemia over 1 year?
questions.solution: Ans. B) 16

choices.text: At the dermo epidermal junction
In dermal papillae
In dermal vessel walls

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of pruritic blister formation. Physical examination shows multiple 1-3 cm bullae on the palms, soles, lower legs, and inguinal folds. Gentle rubbing of the skin does not result in sloughing of the epidermis. Immunofluorescence studies of a perilesional skin biopsy specimen are most likely to show deposition of antibodies in which of the following areas?
questions.solution: Ans. A) At the dermo epidermal junction

questions.text: In a region, health officials report that the prevalence of a certain infectious disease is greater than 5% among high-risk populations but less than 1% among pregnant women. How should this region be classified in terms of disease prevalence?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Moderate prevalence region

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image below?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Automated External Defibrillator

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and coronary artery disease. Current medications include metformin, aspirin, pravastatin, and losartan. Her body mass index is 30 kg/m2. Her hemoglobin A1c concentration is 8%. She does not want to start insulin injection therapy and is afraid that a new medication is going to cause weight gain. Empagliflozin is added to her diabetes regimen. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following adverse effects of this new drug?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Vaginal candidiasis

choices.text: Incorporation of viral genome into host cell DNA
Transcription of the viral genome
Fusion and entry into CD4 T-cells
Attachment to host CD4 T-cells

questions.text: An investigator is conducting an experiment to develop a new drug against HIV infection. HIV-infected and uninfected CD4 T-cell lines are mixed in-vitro with a chemically modified synthetic peptide triazole complex. The complex is found to have a high binding affinity to the gp 120 protein, irreversibly inhibiting its function and reducing CD4 T cell infection. Inhibition of which of the following steps of HIV infection is the most likely therapeutic effect of this experimental drug?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Attachment to host CD4 T-cells

questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a review meeting with the Auxiliary Nurse Midwives (ANMs) at the block level. During the meeting, he discusses various health indicators, including the crude birth rate (CBR) and the expected number of pregnancies. He explains that understanding these numbers is essential for planning and resource allocation. One of the subcenters has a crude birth rate (CBR) of 20 per 1000 people. What is the minimum expected number of pregnancies that should be registered with that ANM?
questions.solution: Ans. C) 55

a-IV, b-I, c-III, d-II

questions.text:
Match List A (foods) with List B (Rich in nutrients) and select the correct answer using the codes given below:

 

List A (Foods)

a. Papaya fruit

b. Soya beans

c. Ragi

d. Amla fruit

 

List B (Nutrients)

I. Calcium

II. Vitamin C

III. Protein

IV. Vitamin A
questions.solution: Ans. C) a-IV, b-III, c-I, d-II

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to express the strength of sewage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E. Coli Count

 

“Sewage strength” generally refers to organic and solids load affecting treatment — measured by BOD, COD, and suspended solids — which determine treatment design and oxygen demand. E. coli count reflects fecal contamination/health hazard but is not a measure of organic strength for engineering purposes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Suspended particles: Suspended solids are a primary parameter indicating particulate load and affect settling and treatment.

 

Option C. COD (Chemical Oxygen Demand): COD quantifies oxygen equivalents for organic/inorganic oxidizable matter — central to sewage strength assessment.

 

Option D. BOD (Biochemical Oxygen Demand): BOD is the classic operational parameter measuring biodegradable organic load and is essential for defining sewage strength.

choices.text: Contamination of reheated hospital food
Colonization of the air conditioning system
Entry through colonized intravenous catheters
Insufficient adherence to hand hygiene measures

questions.text: Ten days after undergoing left hip replacement, a 73-year-old hospitalized man develops a fever, dyspnea, cough productive of yellow sputum, confusion, nausea, and diarrhea. Several patients in the hospital report similar symptoms. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds on the left side and inspiratory crackles over the left lung. An x-ray of the chest shows opacities in the lower lobe of the left lung. Treatment with ampicillin does not improve his symptoms. Subsequent evaluation of the patient's urine detects a pathogen-specific antigen, confirming the diagnosis. Which of the following sources of infection is most likely responsible for this local disease outbreak?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Colonization of the air conditioning system

choices.text: Fishers exact test
Analysis of variance

questions.text: A clinical trial is conducted to determine the role of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) beta-amyloid levels as a biomarker in the early detection and prognosis of Alzheimer disease. A total of 100 participants are enrolled and separated into three groups according to their Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score: mild dementia (20-24 points), moderate dementia (13-20 points), and severe dementia (< 13 points). Participants' CSF level of beta-amyloid 42 is measured using an immunoassay. It is found that participants with severe dementia have a statistically significantly lower mean CSF level of beta-amyloid 42 compared to the other two groups. Which of the following statistical tests was most likely used to compare measurements between the study groups?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Analysis of variance

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of a pruritic rash on the cubital fossae of the upper extremities. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. A skin biopsy of the rash shows intrapidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Eczematous dermatitis

Match the following methods of mosquito control with their examples:

 

Column A

questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient is scheduled for elective surgery and requires endotracheal intubation. Arrange the steps of intubation in the correct sequence.

 

  1. Neck extension and flexion
  2. Introduction of laryngoscope
  3. Inflation of cuff
  4. Checking air entry by stethoscope
questions.solution: Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

choices.text: Elevated serum thyroxine concentration
Elevated glycated hemoglobin concentration
Elevated serum prostate-specific antigen

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of increased urinary frequency. He wakes up several times a night to urinate and feels fatigued during the day. He also complains of increased thirst; he drinks multiple liters of water and soda daily and still feels thirsty. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows patches of velvety hyperpigmentation in the axillae and on the posterior neck. Laboratory evaluation in this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Elevated glycated hemoglobin concentration

questions.text:
A public health officer is outlining the responsibilities of a male health worker in a community health center. Which of the following are included in the job duties of a male health worker?

 

  1. Sputum collection
  2. ORS distribution
  3. DOTS supervision
  4. Growth monitoring
  5. Environmental sanitation

 

Use the following key to mark the correct answer:
questions.solution: Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 5

choices.text: Everyone is given Diphtheria vaccine
Everyone is given Tetanus toxoid
Everyone is given Cholera vaccine
Only the health workers are given Cholera, Typhoid, and Tetanus toxoid

questions.text: In the aftermath of a natural disaster, a public health team is tasked with implementing a vaccination protocol to prevent outbreaks of infectious diseases among the affected population. Considering the increased risk of certain infections in post-disaster settings, which of the following vaccination strategies is most appropriate?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Only the health workers are given Cholera, Typhoid, and Tetanus toxoid

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of a painless growth in his mouth. Physical examination shows white patches on the oral mucosa along the gums that cannot be scraped off with gauze. The lesions have a granular texture. A combination HIV-1/2 immunoassay is negative. A biopsy of the lesion shows a marked increase in the thickness of the stratum corneum and the presence of nucleated keratinocytes in this layer. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral hairy leukoplakia

 

The most likely diagnosis is Oral hairy leukoplakia. Presents as white patches on the oral mucosa, especially on the lateral tongue or along the gums, which cannot be scraped off. Lesions often have a granular or corrugated (hairy) texture, typical for oral hairy leukoplakia. Histology shows marked hyperkeratosis with presence of nucleated keratinocytes (parakeratosis) in the upper epithelial layers. Typically caused by Epstein-Barr virus infection of oral mucosal cells. Common in immunocompromised patients but may rarely occur in immunocompetent individuals. Negative HIV test excludes oral candidiasis as a likely diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral candidiasis: White plaques are scrapeable and removable, revealing erythematous base. Also Oral candidiasis is commonly seen in Immunocompromised patients often who are HIV positive Histology shows fungal hyphae invading the superficial keratin layer.

 

Option B. Lichen Planus: Causes white, lacy (reticular) plaques or erosive lesions on oral mucosa, often painful. Histologically shows a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate with basal cell degeneration. Lesions are usually bilateral and symmetrical, unlike leukoplakia.

 

Option D. Diphtheria: Characterized by a thick gray pseudomembrane in the oropharynx or tonsils, causing sore throat and systemic symptoms. Histopathology reveals fibrinous exudate and necrotic debris, not keratinocyte proliferation or hyperkeratosis

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of sudden-onset fever, malaise, and pain and swelling of his wrists and ankles that began a week ago. One month ago, he was started on hydralazine for adjunctive treatment of hypertension. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). Examination shows swelling, tenderness, warmth, and erythema of both wrists and ankles; range of motion is limited. Further evaluation is most likely to show an increased level of which of the following autoantibodies?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Anti-histone

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of severe pain in her left knee. To lose weight, she recently started jogging for 30 minutes a few times per week. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension treated with metformin and chlorothiazide. On examination, her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 138/87 mm Hg. The left knee is swollen and tender to palpation with a significantly impaired range of motion. A 1.5 cm. painless ulcer is seen on the plantar surface of the left foot. Which of the following is most likely to help establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perform arthrocentesis

 

The clinical presentation of acute severe knee pain with swelling, fever, impaired range of motion, and a painless foot ulcer in a diabetic patient suggests possible septic arthritis or gouty arthritis, among other differential diagnoses.

 

  • Arthrocentesis (joint aspiration) is the most important diagnostic step to differentiate between septic arthritis, crystal-induced arthritis (gout or pseudogout), or inflammatory arthritis by analyzing synovial fluid for:
    • White blood cell count
    • Gram stain and culture (to identify infection)
    • Crystal analysis (urate or calcium pyrophosphate crystals).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Measuring HLA-B27: Is useful in diagnosing seronegative spondyloarthropathies, which is less likely here.

 

Option C. Measure rheumatoid factor: Rheumatoid factor is used in rheumatoid arthritis diagnosis but is less useful acutely.

 

Option D. Perform serum uric acid: Serum uric acid can be elevated in gout but is not diagnostic during an acute attack and cannot rule out infection

questions.text: A clinical trial is conducted to determine the efficacy of ginkgo biloba in the treatment of Parkinson disease. A sample of patients with Parkinson disease is divided into two groups. Participants in the first group are treated with ginkgo biloba, and participants in the other group receive a placebo. A change in the MDS-UPDRS score is used as the primary endpoint for the study. The investigators, participants, and data analysts were meant to be blinded throughout the trial. However, while the trial is being conducted, the patient's demographics and their allocated treatment groups are mistakenly disclosed to the investigators, but not to the participants or the data analysts, because of a technical flaw. The study concludes that there is a significant decrease in MDS-UPDRS scores in patients treated with ginkgo biloba. Which of the following is most likely to have affected the validity of this study?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Pygmalion effect

choices.text: Loss of vision

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of a painful rash on his right flank. Two years ago, he underwent cadaveric renal transplantation. Current medications include tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil, and prednisone. Examination shows an erythematous rash with grouped vesicles in a band-like distribution over the patient's right flank. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Sensory neuropathy

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician for a pre-employment wellness examination. A tuberculin skin test is administered and he develops a raised, erythematous 12 mm lesion on his forearm within 48 hours. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. He is started on the recommended antibiotic treatment for latent tuberculosis. Four weeks later, he returns for a follow-up examination. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.3 g/dL, serum alanine aminotransferase activity of 86 U/L, and serum aspartate aminotransferase activity of 66 U/L. A photomicrograph of a Prussian blue-stained bone marrow smear is shown. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the drug responsible for this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis

 

The Prussian blue-stained bone marrow photomicrograph shows ringed sideroblasts, which are erythroid precursors containing iron-laden mitochondria. This is a classic finding in sideroblastic anemia, which can be caused by isoniazid toxicity—a drug used for latent tuberculosis. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis and can lead to pyridoxine deficiency, impairing heme synthesis and causing iron accumulation in the mitochondria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase: Sulfonamides, not used for TB.

 

Option B. Binding to 50S ribosomal subunit: Macrolides/chloramphenicol.

 

Option D. Inhibition of arabinosyltransferase: Ethambutol, another TB drug but not linked to sideroblastic anemia.

choices.text: Methoxyflurane> Halothane> Isoflurane> Nitrous oxide
Methoxyflurane> Isoflurane> Halothane> Nitrous oxide

questions.text: Arrange the following anaesthetic agents on the basis of their potency?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Methoxyflurane> Halothane> Isoflurane> Nitrous oxide

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 32 weeks' gestation is evaluated for vaginal bleeding. Five days ago, she was admitted to the hospital and started on treatment for a deep vein thrombosis in the right leg. Her pulse is 125/min and blood pressure is 95/67 mm Hg. Physical examination shows large hematomas on the upper limbs and swelling in the right calf. There is a large amount of bright red blood in the vaginal vault. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 8.9 mg/dL, platelet count of 185,000/ mm, and activated partial thromboplastin time of 160 seconds (N-30s). Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to rapidly reverse this patient's coagulopathy?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Protamine sulfate

questions.text: In a health policy discussion, experts are evaluating the adequacy of health manpower in a region. They are considering various benchmarks to determine whether the current health workforce meets the needs of the population. Which of the following ratios is commonly used as an indicator of adequate health manpower?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Lab technician 1 per 10000 population

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the paediatrics clinic after a recent accident that resulted in the amputation of right hand. His parents express concern about his ability to perform daily activities and engage in schoolwork. In this context, the child's inability to perform routine tasks due to the loss of his hands is best described as which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Disability

questions.solution: Ans. D) It is associated with high incidence of nausea and vomiting

Literacy rate and mean years of schooling, per capita income, and average life expectancy

questions.text: Which of the following sets of indicators are included in HDI?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Literacy rate and mean years of schooling, per capita income, and average life expectancy

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is evaluated because of a 3-day history of headache, nausea, and decreased urination. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.28 and a HCO3 concentration of 14 mEq/L. Prolonged treatment with which of the following drugs would best explain this patient's findings?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Amphotericin B

choices.text: It overcomes limitations in the quality of individual studies.
It is able to provide evidence of causality.
The results are less precise.
The likelihood of type II errors is decreased.

questions.text: A group of environmental health scientists recently performed a nationwide cross-sectional study that investigated the risk of head and neck cancers in patients with a history of cigar and pipe smoking. In collaboration with three teams of epidemiologists that have each conducted similar cross-sectional studies in their respective countries, they have agreed to contribute their data to an international pooled analysis of the relationship between non-cigarette tobacco consumption and prevalence of head and neck cancers. Which of the following statements regarding the pooled analysis in comparison to the individual studies is true?
questions.solution: Ans. D) The likelihood of type II errors is decreased.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of progressive hair loss from his scalp. He first noticed receding of the hairline over the bitemporal regions of his scalp 5 years ago. Since then, his hair has gradually become thinner over the crown of his head. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Examination shows diffuse, nonscarring hair loss over the scalp with a bitemporal pattern of recession. Administration of which of the following drugs is most appropriate to treat this patient's hair loss?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Finasteride

choices.text: New heart murmur

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 4-day history of arthralgia, abdominal pain, and lesions on his arms and legs. Ten days ago, he had an upper respiratory tract infection. A photograph of his right leg is shown. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Hematuria

choices.text: Reversible decrease in FEV1/ FVC ratio
Glomerular subepithelial immune complex deposition
IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies
Hepatocyte infection with hepatitis C virus

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of bilateral erythematous skin lesions on the flexures of the elbows and knees. He has been scratching the areas frequently. He has had similar lesions intermittently for the last 2 years. A photograph of the lesions on the back of the knees is shown. This patient's skin lesions are most likely associated with which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Reversible decrease in FEV1/ FVC ratio

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a dry cough. She has also noticed gradual development of facial discoloration. She has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation. She does not remember which medications she takes. Examination shows blue-gray discoloration of the face and both hands. Diffuse inspiratory crackles are heard. An x-ray of the chest shows reticular opacities around the lung periphery and particularly around the lung bases. The most likely cause of this patient's findings is an adverse effect to which of the following medications?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Amiodarone

questions.text:
Match the following anaesthetic agents with its appropriate property?

 

Drug

1. Propofol

2. Fentanyl

3. Etomidate

4. Ketamine

 

Adverse Effect

a. Rigid chest syndrome

b. Dissociative anesthesia

c. Avoided in patients with egg Allergy

d. Adrenal suppression
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

questions.text: You are leading a seminar on obesity assessment methods for healthcare professionals, emphasizing the importance of using internationally accepted standards. You present information on various indices used to measure obesity and ask the participants to identify the internationally accepted method for measuring obesity. Which of the following methods is internationally accepted for measuring obesity?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Quetelet Index

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution: Ans. C) McCoy blade

questions.text: Which is the most common cardiac rhythm seen in adults experiencing sudden cardiac arrest?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Asystole

choices.text: Proximal convoluted tubule
Ascending loop of Henle

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe headache and vomiting that started after she was hiking in the mountains at high altitude. She normally lives in a city that is close to sea level. Therapy is initiated with a drug that alkalinizes the urine. Which of the following is the most likely site of action of this drug in the kidney?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Proximal convoluted tubule

questions.text: After learning in a lecture that caesarean section rates vary from < 0.5% to over 30% across countries, a student wants to investigate if national caesarean section rates correlate with national maternal mortality rates worldwide. For his investigation, the student obtains population data from an international registry that contains tabulated caesarean section rates and maternal mortality rates from the last 10 years for a total of 119 countries. Which of the following best describes this study design?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Ecological study

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of multiple lesions on his chest and lower extremities. The lesions have progressively increased in size and are not painful or pruritic. Current medications include abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine. A photograph of the lesions is shown. A skin biopsy shows multiple spindle-shaped cells and lymphocytic infiltrate. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alpha-interferon

 

The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient’s lesion is alpha-interferon.

 

Diagnosis and Clinical Reasoning

 

This HIV-positive patient has multiple violaceous, non-tender, slowly progressive nodules and plaques, and skin biopsy demonstrates spindle-shaped cell proliferation with lymphocytic infiltrate—findings classic for Kaposi’s sarcoma. Kaposi’s sarcoma is a vascular tumor associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), especially common in immunocompromised individuals, and can be managed with antiretroviral therapy and, in certain cases, alpha-interferon for its antiviral and antiproliferative effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ganciclovir: An antiviral agent primarily used to treat CMV infections in immunocompromised patients. It is not effective in treating Kaposi's sarcoma as it lacks action against HHV-8 or tumor cells.

 

Option B. Nitazoxanide: An antiparasitic medication used for protozoal infections such as Cryptosporidium and Giardia.

 

Option D. Acyclovir: Used mainly against herpes simplex virus and varicella zoster virus; it does not show efficacy against HHV-8

questions.text: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She has no history of serious illness. She receives a vaccine in which a polysaccharide is conjugated to a carrier protein. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely target of this vaccine?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Streptococcus pneumoniae

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with controlled thyrotoxicosis and carcinoma rectum was undergoing laparoscopic abdominoperineal resection when he experienced decreased blood pressure and heart rate. A mill-wheel murmur was heard, and end-tidal pCO2 dropped from 40 to 10. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Air embolism

choices.text: Dry bone marrow tap
Decreased serum haptoglobin concentration
Positive stool guaiac test
Decreased serum vitamin B9 concentration

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of easy fatigability and dyspnea on exertion. Menopause occurred 5 years ago. Her pulse is 105/min and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor of the nail beds and conjunctivae. A peripheral blood smear is shown. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Positive stool guaiac test

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of high-grade fever, altered mental status, and severe respiratory distress. His family reports that he recently attended a wedding in a rural area of Kozhikode district of Kerala, where he consumed freshly tapped toddy, a local drink. Over the next day, three more individuals from the same wedding presented with similar symptoms. On examination, the patient appears lethargic, disoriented, with reduced chest sounds on the right side. His CSF analysis reveals an elevated protein count with normal glucose and an increase in lymphocytes. Given the clinical presentation and his recent history, which of the following infectious agents is most likely responsible for this outbreak?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Nipah virus

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a persistent cough and a 5 kg weight loss over the past 2 months. Yesterday, she coughed up bloody sputum. She does not smoke. A CT scan of the chest shows a mass in the periphery of the right upper lobe. Histopathologic examination shows glandular cells with papillary components and signet ring cells that stain positive for mucin. An activating mutation of which of the following genes is most likely to have occurred in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) ALK

questions.text: What is the full form of this device?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Artificial Manual Breathing Unit

choices.text: Squamous cell ca

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a lesion on his nose. The lesion appeared 1 year ago and has slowly increased in size since then. There is no associated pain or pruritus. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) BCC

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and decreased urine output for 2 weeks. He has not been to the physician for many years and takes no medications. Serum studies show a urea nitrogen concentration of 42 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 2.3 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows heavy proteinuria. A photomicrograph of a section of a kidney biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Diabetes mellitus

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the risk of symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage associated with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) treatment in severe ischemic stroke. The outcomes of a large randomized controlled trial of ischemic stroke patients is shown. Based on this data, how many patients with severe ischemic stroke would need to be treated with tPA, on average, to contribute to one case of symptomatic intracerebral haemorrhage?
questions.solution: Ans. B) 100

choices.text: Dysfunction of apocrine glands
Formation of superficial epidermal inclusion cyst
Hyperkeratinisation of hair follicles
Increased levels of androgen

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the physician because of skin changes on his face, chest, and back over the past year. Treatment with over-the-counter benzoyl peroxide has been ineffective. Physical examination shows numerous open comedones, inflammatory papules, and pustules on his face, chest, and back. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's skin condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Increased levels of androgen

choices.text: Pseudocholinesterase deficiency increasing action of succinylcholine
Undiagnosed muscular dystrophy and muscular weakness
Muscular weakness due to fasciculation produced by succinylcholine

questions.text: A 70 kg elderly athlete undergoes surgery and is administered succinylcholine due to the unavailability of vecuronium. A total of 640 mg of succinylcholine is given intermittently. During recovery, the patient is unable to breathe spontaneously or move limbs. What is the explanation?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Phase 2 blockade produced by succinylcholine

questions.text: As a part of a public health project, you are analyzing maternal mortality in a town over a six-month period. In this time, there were 2,500 live births. The recorded maternal deaths include 5 due to peripartum infection, 2 due to obstructed labor, and 3 due to postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Deaths due to unrelated causes also occurred such as 10 from electrocution. Based on this data, calculate the Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) for this period.
questions.solution: Ans. A) 4 per 1,000 live births

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation. She has multiple erythematous pustules and nodules over her face, for which she has received erythromycin and topical benzoyl peroxide. She is concerned that the therapy is ineffective. The physician recommends a drug on the condition that the patient agrees to use oral contraceptives. The molecular structure of the drug most likely recommended by the physician closely resembles a drug used to treat which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute promyelocytic leukaemia

 

This patient has severe nodulocystic acne that has not responded to erythromycin and topical benzoyl peroxide. The drug most likely recommended here is oral isotretinoin, a systemic retinoid that is highly effective for severe, treatment-resistant acne. Isotretinoin is a derivative of vitamin A and acts by decreasing sebaceous gland activity, reducing sebum production, and normalizing keratinization. Because of its teratogenic effects, strict contraception with oral contraceptive pills is required in women of childbearing potential. Structurally, isotretinoin resembles all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA), the drug used in the management of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL, M3 AML). ATRA induces differentiation of immature promyelocytes, reversing the maturation arrest that characterizes APL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EGFR-positive non-small cell lung cancer: This condition is treated with EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as erlotinib, gefitinib, and osimertinib. These agents block downstream signaling pathways that drive proliferation and survival of malignant lung cells.

 

Option C. BRAF-positive metastatic melanoma: BRAF V600E mutation–positive melanomas are treated with targeted therapy using BRAF inhibitors (eg, vemurafenib, dabrafenib), often combined with MEK inhibitors (trametinib). These agents inhibit the MAPK/ERK pathway to suppress uncontrolled cell growth. They are kinase inhibitors and have no similarity in structure or mechanism to retinoids.

 

Option D. HER2-positive gastric cancer: This is managed with trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody that targets HER2/neu receptors, blocking proliferative signaling and mediating antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity.

choices.text: Vitamin C prophylaxis is effective in preventing the condition.
The condition presents with 1-stick stage, 2-stick stage.
Parboiling can detoxicate the pulses causing the condition.
Sanguinarine is the underlying causative toxin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer presents with a history of progressive weakness and spasticity in his lower limbs. He reports a diet primarily consisting of pulses from his recent harvest. On examination, he shows signs of hyperreflexia and spastic gait. Which of the following statements are not true about the condition that this patient is suffering from?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Sanguinarine is the underlying causative toxin.

choices.text: Skin, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, dura mater, arachnoid mater
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, epidural space, dura mater
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space, dura mater, arachnoid mater
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, subdural space, arachnoid mater

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the hospital for an elective hernia repair surgery. The anesthesiologist decides to administer spinal anesthesia for the procedure. During the administration, the needle is carefully advanced through which anatomical layers to reach the subarachnoid space?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space, dura mater, arachnoid mater

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of severe itching in the area of her genitals. She reports that the itching is most severe at night. Her current sexual partner is experiencing similar symptoms. Pelvic examination shows vulvar excoriations. A photomicrograph of an epilated pubic hair is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phthirus pubis

 

This patient presents with intense nocturnal genital pruritus and vulvar excoriations, along with her partner having similar symptoms. The photomicrograph of an epilated pubic hair shows Phthirus pubis (crab louse) attached to the hair shaft. These lice are transmitted mainly via sexual contact and cause irritation due to hypersensitivity reactions to louse saliva. Clinical findings include erythematous papules, excoriations, and sometimes visible lice or nits on pubic hair. Treatment involves topical pediculicides such as permethrin or malathion, along with partner treatment and linen decontamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pediculus humanus: This species includes Pediculus humanus capitis (head louse) and Pediculus humanus corporis (body louse). Head lice infest the scalp, causing pruritus, while body lice are vectors for diseases such as epidemic typhus and trench fever. They are not typically restricted to the genital area.

 

Option C. Epidermophyton floccosum: A dermatophyte fungus that causes superficial skin infections like tinea cruris (jock itch), tinea pedis, and tinea corporis. It presents as well-demarcated, scaly, erythematous lesions, not nocturnal itching with parasites attached to hair shafts.

 

Option D. Sarcoptes scabiei: This mite causes scabies, which presents with intense nocturnal itching, burrows, and papular eruptions in interdigital webs, wrists, axillae, and genitalia.

choices.text: Defective beta-2 integrin
Defective CD40 ligand
Defective NADPH oxidase
Defective lysosomal trafficking regulator gene

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of recurrent infections and easy bruising. He has been hospitalized 3 times for severe skin and respiratory infections, which responded to treatment with antibiotics. Examination shows sparse silvery hair. The skin is hypopigmented and there are diffuse petechiae. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 8 g/dL, leukocyte count of 3000/mm3,  and platelet count of 45,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Defective lysosomal trafficking regulator gene

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of lower leg weakness, swallowing difficulty, and drooling of saliva. He has not yet received any childhood vaccinations. Two days after admission, the patient develops shortness of breath. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 64%. Despite resuscitative efforts, the patient dies of respiratory failure. At autopsy, examination of the spinal cord shows destruction of the anterior horn cells. Neurological examination of this patient would have most likely shown which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyporeflexia

 

  • Anterior horn cells = lower motor neurons (LMN).
  • Damage leads to LMN signs: muscle weakness, hypotonia, fasciculations, hyporeflexia/areflexia.
  • Classical for poliomyelitis (unvaccinated child, anterior horn cell destruction).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive Babinski sign: Indicates UMN lesion (corticospinal tract damage), not LMN.

 

Option B. Clasp knife spasticity: Also a feature of UMN lesions due to loss of inhibitory control.

 

Option D. Sensory loss: Sensory pathways remain intact in polio → no sensory deficit.

questions.text: A geriatric investigator is evaluating the consistency of Alzheimer dementia diagnoses based on clinical symptoms. Patients with known chart diagnoses of Alzheimer dementia were evaluated by multiple physicians during a fixed time interval. Each evaluator was blinded to the other's assessments. The extent to which the diagnosis by one physician was replicated by another clinician examining the same patient is best described by which of the following terms?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Precision

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a recurrent vesicular genital rash comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of a painful, pruritic rash that began on the extremities and has spread to her trunk. Her only medication is acyclovir. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Examination of the skin shows several reddish-purple papules and macules, some of which have a dusky center with a lighter ring around them. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Erythema multiforme

questions.text: A group of medical students is organizing an educational event where a series of experts will give speeches on specialized topics. The format of the event is such that each expert will present their knowledge and findings, but there will be no discussion or interaction among the speakers themselves. What is this type of event commonly called in academic and professional settings?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Symposium

choices.text: Where subdistrict or district hospitals are not present
Referral center for 2–3 Urban Primary Health Centers (PHCs)
For cities with a population of 1–1.5 lakh (100,000–150,000)
100-bed capacity in metro cities

questions.text: A healthcare administrator is planning to establish an Urban Community Health Center (CHC) and is considering the essential criteria to ensure the facility meets the necessary standards and serves the community effectively. Which of the following criteria are important for establishing an Urban CHC?
questions.solution: Ans. D) 100-bed capacity in metro cities

choices.text: Pruritus and flushing of the skin

questions.text: A 53-year-old man with hyperlipidemia comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His home medications include acetaminophen and atorvastatin. Serum studies show elevated total cholesterol and triglyceride concentrations. A drug that activates the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha is added to his existing therapy. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following drug-related adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reddish-brown discoloration of urine

 

This occurs due to myopathy or rhabdomyolysis, a known serious adverse effect of fibrates (PPAR-alpha activators) especially when combined with statins like atorvastatin. The muscle breakdown releases myoglobin, which colors the urine reddish-brown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waxing and waning confusion: This is not associated with fibrates; it suggests neurological causes unrelated to this drug class.

 

Option C. Pruritus and flushing of the skin: These are typical side effects of niacin, not fibrates.

 

Option D. Acutely swollen and painful joint: While fibrates can elevate uric acid levels increasing gout risk, this is less common than rhabdomyolysis and urine discoloration.

questions.text:
Match the following vectors with the diseases they transmit:

 

Column A

1. Housefly

2. Sandfly

3. Tse-Tse fly

4. Black fly

 

Column B

A. Oroya fever

B. Yaws

C. Sleeping sickness

D. Onchocerciasis
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d

choices.text: Useful in situations where PO2 is low
Causes impairment in renal function

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is being managed in the ICU. The intensivist decides to implement Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) in his ventilatory support. Which of the following statements about PEEP is incorrect?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Decreases intracranial tension (ICT)

questions.text:
Primary level of prevention includes?

 

1. Screening of disease

2. Quarantine

3. Isolation

4. Diagnosis

5. Vaccination
questions.solution: Ans. C) 2, 3, 5

questions.text: A previously healthy 41-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a 1-month history of painless, intermittent bleeding on defecation, which he discovered while wiping. His younger sister was recently diagnosed with endometrial cancer, and his mother was diagnosed with gastric cancer at 58 years of age. Colonoscopy shows a tumor in the ascending colon. A mutation of which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) MLH-1

choices.text: Decreased sensation over the cheekbone, nasolabial fold, and the upper lip
Hemiatrophy of the tongue with right-sided deviation when protruded
Abnormal taste of the distal tongue and decreased sensation behind the ear
Absent corneal reflex and decreased sensation of the forehead

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressively worsening headaches and fatigue. She has also had a 5-kg weight loss in the same time period. MRI of the head shows a hyperintense mass with extension into the right foramen rotundum. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Decreased sensation over the cheekbone, nasolabial fold, and the upper lip

questions.text: An investigator is studying the frequency of polycythemia in a population of a remote, mountainous region. A representative sample of 100 men shows a normal distribution of hemoglobin concentration with a mean concentration of 17g/dl and a standard error of 0.1 g/dl.  Which of the following best represents the probability that a subject will have a hemoglobin concentration greater than 18 g/dL?
questions.solution: Ans. B) 16%

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of fever and a pruritic rash that started on his trunk and then progressed to his face and extremities. He has not received any childhood vaccinations because his parents believe that they are dangerous. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Varicella

choices.text: Duration can be prolonged using an inlaying catheter

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of epidural over spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duration can be prolonged using an inlaying catheter

 

  • Epidural anaesthesia:
    • Involves injection of local anaesthetic into the epidural space outside the dura.
    • A catheter can be inserted, allowing continuous or repeated dosing, so anaesthesia duration can be extended as needed.
  • Spinal anaesthesia:
    • Single-shot injection into the subarachnoid space; limited duration and cannot be prolonged without another puncture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Less dose of drug required: False. spinal anaesthesia typically requires less drug due to direct intrathecal injection.

 

Option C. Easier technique: False. epidural is technically more difficult than spinal.

 

Option D. Less traumatic needle: False. spinal needles are usually smaller and less traumatic; epidural needles are larger and more invasive.

questions.text:
Match the following research institutes with their corresponding locations:

 

Column A

  1. National JALMA Institute for Leprosy
  2. National Institute of Occupational Health (NIOH)
  3. National Institute of Epidemiology
  4. National AIDS Research Institute (NARI)

 

Column B

  1. Pune
  2. Ahmedabad
  3. Agra
  4. Chennai
questions.solution: Ans. B) a-3, b-2, c-4, d-1

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of high fever and confusion for the past 10 hours. His wife reports that 1 week ago he underwent an emergency appendectomy. His temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), pulse is 132/min, and blood pressure is 74/46 mm Hg. He is oriented only to person. Physical examination shows a surgical wound in the right lower quadrant with purulent discharge. The skin is warm and dry. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 138 mEq/L, potassium concentration of 3.7 mEq/L, and lactate concentration of 3.5 mEq/L (N = 0.5-2.2 mEq/L). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these laboratory changes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Respiratory fatigue

 

  • Septic shock with fatigue → hypoventilation leads to respiratory acidosis on top of lactic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperventilation: Early sepsis, not late.

 

Option B. Primary adrenal insufficiency: Not suggested here.

 

Option C. Salicylate toxicity: Not related to presentation.

questions.text: Which of the following strategies is an example of primordial prevention for coronary heart disease?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Salt restriction

choices.text: Gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacilli
Gram-positive, coagulase-positive cocci

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 6-hour history of severe eye pain and blurry vision. He wears soft contact lenses and has not removed them for 2 days. Ophthalmologic examination shows a deep corneal ulcer, severe conjunctival injection, and purulent discharge on the right. Treatment with topical ciprofloxacin is initiated. A culture of the ocular discharge is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacilli

choices.text: All antihypertensives should be continued without any exception
Thyroid supplements should be mandatorily stopped before surgery

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, and chronic steroid use is scheduled for elective surgery. Which of the following is a true statement regarding the continuation of medications before surgery?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Clopidogrel should be stopped 1 week prior to surgery

questions.text: In a laboratory setting where strict sterilization protocols are necessary to prevent contamination, different methods are used to sterilize various materials. Which is the best method recommended for TB sputum?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Incineration

choices.text: Concentric periductal fibrosis
Mallory Denk bodies
Necrosis with neutrophilic infiltrate

questions.text: Two weeks after returning from vacation, a 21-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of malaise, nausea, vomiting, fever, and abdominal pain. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and right upper quadrant tenderness. The liver is palpated 1.5 cm below the right costal margin. A biopsy specimen of this patient's liver would most likely show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Ballooning of hepatocytes

questions.text: A new rapid test for the diagnosis of a viral respiratory infection is evaluated in 200 study participants. At a given cutoff, the test shows a true-negative rate of approximately 70% and a true-positive rate of approximately 65%. Which of the following labeled graphs is most likely to represent this diagnostic test?
questions.solution: Ans. B) B.
